comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Eddie Campi was a bantamweight boxer. See www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/campi-eddie.htm Jess Willard was a heavyweight boxer. See NYT of March 19, 1916 "Jess Willard, the massive Kansas cowboy, who is the heavyweight champion pugilist of the world, is a firm believer in the never disputed fact that a straight line is the shortest distance between two points. In Willard's repertoirs of punches, there are no swings and trick blows, he hits straight from the shoulder and hits hard." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C00E7D6153DEF3AB...

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Thanks swanq for the link to the story confirming that Jess Willard is indeed a heavyweight boxer, and Eddie Campi was a bantamweight boxer.  In fact, dates for Campi give us a better date range for the photograph.  The question remains: Is that Bill James who played baseball for Boston on the left?

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: I had wondered the same. The outfit and the background structure suggest a baseball connection. pro.corbis.com/search/Enlargement.aspx?CID=isg&mediauid={128D74D7-1320-44AC-ACF0-C99804CE2BD3} is a 1914 picture of the Boston pitcher. Could be the same guy.

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Thanks swanq for the links to other images of Bill James.  I'm still not sure that he's the same person as the pitcher for the Boston Braves.  I think we'll have to hold off making the connection until more information comes in.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content:
This Bill James is dressed in a baseball uniform with a pitcher's warmup jacket. But there were two pitchers of this era with the same name. 
Big Bill James born 1887 and Seattle Bill James, born 1892:

I can't get the direct links to work in Flickr syntax, but follow this one and then link to Bill James (disambiguation)
